utterances: The remaining members of the Petits Chanteurs, Haiti's renowned boy's and men's chorus, began the first post-quake concert by serenading Bel Air, a downtown neighborhood that's still choked with dusty debris.
(Soundbite of chorus singing)
Questions now about new airport security rules announced this week by the Transportation Security Administration.
Passengers from 14 countries are now subject to extra screening.
Do these rules make flying safer, and do they violate civil liberties?
Not only, no. In this country, the live grows wild on the hills, in the woodland.

In the early Bronze Age, four millennia BC, they were already cultivating the olives on a large scale and everybody whoever lived in this country more or less used to produce olive oil and we're still producing olive oil on a large scale.
I can see an olive tree out of the--I'm looking out of the window and I can see an olive tree there.
Rafael Frankel edited the history and technology of olive oil in the Holy Land.
We reached him at his home in the western Galilee.
Thank you, sir.
Thank you.
We're in the last few weeks of the Supreme Court's current term, and justices still have loads of decisions to hand down - two dozen, to be precise.
And some of those may come as soon as Monday.
We'll bring in NPR's legal affairs correspondent Nina Totenberg.
Nina, thanks so much for being with us.
My pleasure, as always, Scott.
Twenty-four cases in which there are no decision.
I gather a dozen could be of particular interest.
Which ones do you most anticipate?
Well, there are three big ones.
The first is what I call the cross case.
This is a giant cross on public property in Bladensburg, Md.
It's a World War I war memorial.
And civil libertarians have objected to it because they see the cross as a symbol of Christianity and that it ought to be on private property, maintained with private funds, not taxpayer money.
We're going to see what the court does with that.
My suspicion is that they're going to let the cross stand.
And whatever they write probably will have a lot of impact on religious symbol cases in the future.
And then there's a gerrymandering case from North Carolina and from Maryland - how state legislatures draw the lines, in this case, for congressional districts.
And they do it usually to entrench their own political power.
But it's gotten, with the advent of computers, kind of wild.
And the Supreme Court is being asked again, is there any limit beyond which politicians can't go to entrench themselves in political power?

And then the last case is a test of the addition of the citizenship question on the census, a question that hasn't been there in 70 years and that opponents of the question claim would lead to a big undercount.
And they say that the Trump administration is doing it for partisan reasons.
Why are there still so many outstanding cases?

Well, I don't actually know, except one has to assume there are very big differences among the justices, between the court's five Conservatives and four Liberals - Justice Ginsburg hinted at that in a recent speech - but also, even among the Conservatives themselves, the rationales for how they're going to rule.
There are rumors around that there's a lot of bad blood going on.
But you couldn't tell that by what the justices say about each other, even privately when they know that they're being listened to.
As you see it, what's at stake for the court this term?
Well, there's no secret about this.
The chief justice has been very clear.
He doesn't want the court to be seen as a partisan institution.
The other members of the court, both liberal and conservative, go around saying that this isn't a partisan institution at all.
That's the message they want to convey, which is sort of hard at the moment.

But is that possible in this day and age, when we know by their - in their own account, conservative Republicans have tried to win elections so they can win Supreme Court appointments and you have several Democrats running for president now on the issue of enlarging the court?
You know, I wish I knew whether it's even possible anymore to have a Supreme Court that doesn't look partisan.
I had always thought you really could.

But if you look at the two cases before the court that are overtly partisan, the gerrymandering case and the census case, both would structurally allow Republicans to entrench their power even more than they have in the last decade or two.
And I think it gets harder to sell the court as an apolitical institution, which is, as I said, what every member of the Supreme Court still tries to do.
You know, I interviewed Justice Stevens about a month and a half ago for a piece about his new book.
And even he, a lifetime Republican, although deemed a Liberal on the court, appointed by President Ford, said it was hard for him to see the current court as apolitical.
He said he still has hope, and so do I, but it's difficult.
NPR's Nina Totenberg, thanks so much.
Thank you, Scott.
Al Franken served in the U.S.
Senate for just under a decade, representing the state of Minnesota.
But in late 2017, when Franken was accused by several women of touching or kissing them in inappropriate ways, his career was derailed.
There was all kinds of pressure on him to resign, and eventually, he announced on the Senate floor that he would do just that.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
I of all people am aware that there is some irony in the fact that I am leaving, while a man who has bragged on tape about his history of sexual assault sits in the Oval Office.
Al Franken has stayed out of the public eye ever since, but he's now gone on the record with his first major interview since his resignation.
He talked with New Yorker staff writer Jane Mayer, who joins us now.
Hi, Jane.
Hi.
How are you?
I'm well.
Thanks for being here.
So you asked former Senator Al Franken flat-out whether he regrets his decision to walk away from the Senate.
What did he say?
He said he absolutely regrets that he resigned.
And it was interesting to me.

Seven senators who called on him to resign told me that they also regret it and considered a - one of - in some cases, in the case of Senator Leahy, one of the worst mistakes that they've made since being in the Senate.
So there's been a kind of a reassessment going on.
Why?
I mean, especially Patrick Leahy, who's served for decades in the Senate, he's saying it's the biggest mistake of his political career?
How come?
(Soundbite of music)
I'm Alex Chadwick.
DAY TO DAY continues in a moment.
Well, good.
Could our home computers become part of a network like that, work together?
When everyone sees that global growth is slowing down, it's not just the U.S.
We're also seeing China and Europe slowing down.
They go, oh, no. It's going to be harder than ever to dig our way out of this mess.
Just last year, prospects seemed brighter.
After the financial crisis, the global economy rebounded.
But that growth has now stalled in ways that remind us how the global economy is interwoven.
China, for example, has been booming, in part because of demand for its products in the U.S.
and Europe.
But Kenneth Rogoff points out that with U.S.
and European consumers and businesses cutting back on their spending, even China gets hurt.
Although it's still growing, China's not collapsing at all, it's notably slowing, and it's being affected by the rest of the world.
And all of these things connect, so we're seeing all the major regions of the world slow down, and it's not clear where growth is going to come from in the coming quarters.
Rogoff, the co-author of a book on the history of financial crises, points out that a slowdown like this is typical after a big financial crisis.
In working so hard to get banks to lend again and consumers and businesses to spend again, governments drive themselves deep into debt.
Cornell University economist Eswar Prasad points out that government debt has become a burden for all the big Western economies.
And the high levels of government debt that exist in virtually every advanced economy are going to be a real drag on their growth.
Instead of promoting economic activity, those governments have to focus on financing their debt.
Greece, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Ireland, they're all having trouble getting banks to loan them what they need.
And that prospect has investors here worried, as well, with regard to the U.S.
future.
It adds up to economic trouble for much of the developed world, and also to some realignments.
The new economies, the emerging market countries, are in relatively better shape.

Those that export to the advanced countries are affected by some of their export markets drying up, but Prasad points out that consumers in those countries - China, for example - are making up some of the difference.
Plus, Prasad says, many of these new economies got their own budget deficits under control years ago, leaving them freer now to do more stimulus spending.
Most of the emerging markets have a lot more space in terms of their policies, to prime the pump a little bit if needed to stoke their economies.
So the global economic landscape is shifting, and not in ways that benefit the US or Europe.
Economists say the powerhouses of the past could struggle for years to return to the prosperity they knew previously, even as new economies rise up to challenge them.
Tom Gjelten, NPR News, Washington.
It's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Jacki Lyden.
President Obama has officially begun his second term.
Shortly before noon today, he was cited the 35-word oath of office with Chief Justice John Roberts.
I, Barack Hussein Obama, do solemnly swear...
After the oath, he thanked the chief justice, hugged his wife and daughters and said: I did it.
NPR's Ari Shapiro is at the White House and joins us now.
Hi, Ari.
Hi, Jacki.
